intro: Dipcadi montanum var. madrasicum, commonly known as the Madrasic squill, is a bulbous plant native to the Mediterranean region. It features narrow, grass-like leaves and produces clusters of white or pale blue flowers in the spring. The plant belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its ornamental value and adaptability to well-drained soils. It is often cultivated for its aesthetic appeal and can thrive in full sun to partial shade. Due to its hardiness, it is suitable for rock gardens and borders in temperate climates.
